awd_titl_txt: CSR: CHS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Improving Pedestrian Safety in Urban Cities using Intelligent Wearable Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Using smartphones while walking poses an increasingly common safety problem for people in urban environments. Whether listening to music, texting, or talking, pedestrians that are absorbed with their smartphones are considerably less likely to notice important auditory cues of danger, such as the honks and sounds of approaching vehicles, putting pedestrians at far greater risk of being hit. This project aims to develop an intelligent wearable system that uses miniature microphones - embedded in earphones or headsets - to detect and locate approaching vehicles and warn the wearer of imminent dangers from cars, buses, motorbikes, trucks, and trams. 

The system comprises multiple microphones embedded in a wearable headset, an ultra-low-power feature extraction and data  processing pipeline, and a set of machine-learning classifiers running on a smartphone. This project is organized in four research thrusts: (1) designing an architecture and data processing pipeline for a wearable system composed of heterogeneous embedded modules; (2) devising an ultra-low-power, analog, signal-processing application-specific integrated circuit (ASIC) for energy-efficient, on-board feature extraction; (3) modeling and optimizing machine-learning classifiers for acoustic event detection and localization; and (4) designing an interface and feedback mechanisms that are optimized for the users' perceptual, cognitive, and motor control abilities.

This research will help reduce pedestrian injuries and fatalities, and expand knowledge on designing wearable systems for enhancing safety in cities, workplaces, and the home. The underlying framework can be generalized to other systems - employing low-power signal processors and algorithms to solve real-time sensing and classification problems of many kinds. Research products will be made publicly available to anyone to apply these techniques in their own system designs. Course modules developed on embedded systems, mobile computing, and Internet-of-Things will be used at the three participating universities to train undergraduate and graduate students, and will be made available online.

por.por_cntn:
Pedestrians listening to music, texting, talking, or otherwise absorbed by their phones make themselves extremely vulnerable to accidents by tuning out the traffic around them. To address this problem, in this project, we develop a headset that detects and localizes imminent dangers, such as approaching vehicles, and warns the user in a timely, effective, and personalized manner. The system comprises of multiple microphones embedded inside a wearable headset, an ultra-low-power feature extraction and data processing pipeline, and a set of machine learning classifiers running on a smartphone. This project advances computer systems research by tackling several fundamental systems challenges, such as ultra-low-power embedded system design, real-time acoustic source localization in noisy environments, computation of acoustic features using custom analog processors, and effective feedback mechanisms for a human-in-the-loop system. Wearable technology has previously been mainly focused on fitness, healthcare, and portable human-computer interaction applications, but this project transforms this class of devices to impact the emerging research area of personal safety. The system has been validated with safety-aware headphone prototypes and through multiple experiments in realistic urban environments.

The problem addressed in this project required an interdisciplinary approach since the key research questions being addressed span across the multiple disciplines, e.g., embedded systems, analog signal processing and integrated circuit design, machine learning-based acoustic processing, and human factors. A multidisciplinary team from three different institutions closely collaborated on four research thrusts in (a) designing an architecture and data processing pipeline for a wearable system comprising of heterogeneous embedded modules, (b) devising an ultra-low-power analog signal integrated circuitry for energy-efficient, on-board feature extraction from microphone data, (c) modeling machine learning classifiers for robust and accurate acoustic event detection and localization, and (d) understanding human perception, cognition, and response to design an effect feedback mechanism.

While the project has been focused on pedestrian safety, the architectural, signal processing, electronics design, machine learning and human behavior research questions addressed here will have impact on many more possible applications. For example, by using electromagnetic sensors, cars can be detected based on their electro-magnetic profile to generate warnings which is of particular interest for all-electric vehicles. Similarly, by using multiple sensors on their helmets and with the appropriate extensions to the classifiers, the design of wearable safety devices for bikers can build upon the proposed research. Many Internet-of-Things devices further target ultra-low power dissipation for small battery size and form factor and will benefit from the cross-disciplinary approach proposed here that goes from signals, to circuits, to systems, to algorithms and to human behavior.

The research result has the potential to be commercialized and turned into an affordable wearable headset that will help reduce injuries and fatalities from distracted pedestrians. The design of the system expands our knowledge on designing wearable systems for urban safety. This award has supported the doctoral dissertation research of multiple Ph.D. students in UNC Chapel Hill and Columbia University. Undergraduate courses curricula in each school has been impacted by the research from this program. Female undergraduate students in all schools, including students from the all-women Barnard College, have been involved directly in the research t strengthen their STEM skills. Research results and artifacts have been disseminated and demonstrated to a broader audience across disciplines via programs such as the Columbia-Rio Design Challenge and edX.
